author: Yoruk Bahceli
title: Former Congo leader on ICC bribe charges | African News
text:
Former Congo vice-president Jean-Pierre Bemba in court at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, Netherlands, on Tuesday. He is standing trial with Aime Kilolo Musamba, Jean-Jacques Mangenda Kabongo, Fidele Babala Wandu and Narcisse Arido on charges including corrupting witnesses. Picture: REUTERS/PETER DEJONG Related articles Congo militia chief a ‘revolutionary rebel not criminal’ Congolese militia leader goes on trial at ICC ICC must look at both sides in Ivorian strife, says rights group Sudanese unit accused of mass killings and rape In this article Companies and organisations: International Criminal Court THE HAGUE — Former Democratic Republic of the Congo vice-president Jean-Pierre Bemba went on trial at the International Criminal Court (ICC) on Tuesday for obstructing justice after allegedly trying to corrupt witnesses in his war crimes trial, which is still under way.
Prosecutors say Mr Bemba, whose trial for crimes against humanity opened at the court in The Hague in 2010, hoped flawed testimony would lead to his acquittal in that case.
"This is a case about shielding the integrity of the court’s proceedings," prosecutor Fatou Bensouda said in her opening remarks.
Some of the court’s highest-profile cases have collapsed owing to witness tampering.
Last year, prosecutors abandoned their case against Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta, who was accused of fomenting pre-election violence, because of what they said was large-scale intimidation and bribing of witnesses.
"Mr Bemba directed a plan to see his acquittal through corrupted means," Ms Bensouda said, adding that witness testimony, telephone and money transfer records and logs from the court’s jail would prove her case.
The suspects deny the charges, saying payments were intended to cover witnesses’ expenses and not to influence their testimony.
The defence did not have a chance to reply at Tuesday’s hearing. Mr Bemba followed the session intensely, nodding and tapping his finger as Ms Bensouda spoke.
He is accused of conspiring with former trial lawyer Aime Kilolo Musamba, Jean-Jacques Mangenda Kabongo, another member of his legal team, Fidele Babala Wandu, a politician and close associate, and witness Narcisse Arido to coach witnesses or offer payment for favourable testimony.
In his first trial, he is accused of orchestrating atrocities against civilians in 2002, when soldiers for his Movement for the Liberation of Congo militia intervened in neighbouring Central African Republic.
In court, prosecutors played a tape of Mr Musamba apparently instructing a witness to avoid saying that Mr Bemba had direct control over the militia. In written filings, prosecutors cited witness accounts in which Mr Musamba discussed giving cash sums of about €50 to witnesses and hiding the matter from Mr Bemba’s other lawyers.
"This isn’t corruption," Mr Musamba told one witness, according to prosecutors. "Just a present from Mr Bemba because you agreed to testify in his favour."
The defendants could face up to five years in prison and an unlimited fine if convicted.
Reuters
